src:
Protestniki prižgali kres in zažigali kraljeve slike
Španski kralj je z družino obiskal Barcelono. Pričakali so jih protestniki.
06 Nov 2019, 12:32 by B. K. P.



REUTERSKatalonija nima kralja! so vzklikali protestniki. FOTO: REUTERS



REUTERSKatalonijo znova pretresajo protesti. FOTO: REUTERS



Kraljeva družina je v Barcelono prišla v zelo nevarnem in nemirnem času. FOTO: Guliver/getty Images



Komaj 14-letna princesa se že pripravlja, da bo nekoč od očeta prevzela prestol. FOTO: Guliver/getty Images


Medtem ko v Kataloniji znova divjajo protesti, s katerimi prebivalci zahtevajo neodvisnost, se je španski kralj Felipe VI. odločil, da obišče to nemirno pokrajino.


Kraljeva družina je v Barcelono prišla v zelo nevarnem in nemirnem času. FOTO: Guliver/getty Images

A ljudje ga niso bili prav veseli, pričakali so ga nasprotniki in ob njegovem prihodu so znova izbruhnili protesti. Nasprotniki španskega kralja so na enem od mestnih trgov zakurili kres in zažigali Felipejeve fotografije. Mnogi so tolkli po loncih in posodah ter vzklikali Katalonija nima kralja! Kralj Felipe VI. je Katalonijo v ponedeljek obiskal prvič, odkar je policija pred dvema letoma nasilno ustavila tiste, ki so želeli oddati glasove na prepovedanem referendumu o odcepitvi Katalonije od preostanka Španije. Takrat se je devet politikov in aktivistov, ki so se zavzemali za katalonsko samostojnost, znašlo za rešetkami, kar je sprožilo še bolj nasilne proteste. Več kot 500 ljudi je bilo takrat ranjenih, polovica od njih je bila policistov. In ni videti, da bi se razmere kmalu umirile, saj so pred nekaj tedni izbruhnili novi protesti, ki jih je kraljev prihod le še dodatno razvnel.


Katalonijo znova pretresajo protesti. FOTO: REUTERSREUTERS

Tudi tokrat so ljudi razburile državnozborske volitve, ki so potekale v nedeljo, na enem od soočenj pa je aktualni premier Pedro Sanchez izjavil, da bo, če bo znova zmagala socialistična stranka, spremenil zakon, po katerem bo organizacija neprijavljenih referendumov postala kaznivo dejanje. Še dodatnega olja na ogenj je prilil vodja skrajno desničarske stranke Vox Santiago Abascal, ki je na enem od soočenj pristojne pozval, naj aretirajo katalonskega predsednika Quima Torra ter ga zaradi njegovih dejanj pripeljejo pred sodišče.Obisk kralja Felipeja, ki so se mu pridružile tudi žena in hčerki, ni imel nobene povezave s protesti, volitvami ali neodvisnostjo. V Katalonijo Felipe ni prišel mirit strasti, temveč se je družina udeležila podelitve nagrad mladim podjetnikom, znanstvenikom in umetnikom. Na podelitvi je spregovorila tudi njegova starejša hči, 14-letna princesa Leonor, ki bo na prestolu nekoč nasledila očeta.
Policisti so z barikadami onemogočili, da bi se kdo približal stavbi, kjer je potekala prireditev, za promet so zaprli mestne vpadnice.
V govoru, ki ga je podala tako v španščini kot katalonščini, se je najstnica dotaknila svoje ljubezni do tega dela domovine ter dejala, da ima Katalonija v njenem srcu od nekdaj posebno mesto. Zahteven podvig je bila medtem varnost kraljevih. Policisti, ki jih je okrog dvorane v Barceloni kar mrgolelo, so denimo z barikadami onemogočili, da bi se kdo približal stavbi, kjer je potekala prireditev, za ves promet pa so zaprli vse glavne mestne vpadnice.
text:
Protesters lit a bonfire and set fire to royal images
The Spanish king visited Barcelona with his family. They were greeted by protesters.
06 Nov 2019, 12:32 by B. K. P.



REUTERSCatalonia has no king! the protesters exclaimed. PHOTO: REUTERS



REUTERSCatalonia is again shaken by protests. PHOTO: REUTERS



The royal family came to Barcelona at a very dangerous and turbulent time. PHOTO: Gulliver / getty Images



The barely 14-year-old princess is already preparing to take the throne one day from her father. PHOTO: Gulliver / getty Images


While in Catalonia the protests with which residents demand independence are raging again, the king of Spain, Felipe VI. decided to visit this turbulent landscape.


The royal family came to Barcelona at a very dangerous and turbulent time. PHOTO: Gulliver / getty Images

But people were not happy about him, his opponents were waiting for him, and on his arrival protests erupted again. Opponents of the Spanish king lit a bonfire in one of the city's squares and burned Felipe's photos. Many were banging on pots and pans and shouting Catalonia has no king! King Felipe VI. visited Catalonia on Monday for the first time since police violently stopped two years ago those seeking to cast their votes in a banned referendum on secession of Catalonia from the rest of Spain. At the time, nine politicians and activists advocating Catalan independence were behind bars, sparking even more violent protests. More than 500 people were injured at the time, half of them police officers. And the situation does not appear to be easing anytime soon, as a few weeks ago new protests broke out, only further developed by the king's arrival.


Catalonia is again shaken by protests. PHOTO: REUTERSREUTERS

This time, too, people were upset by the parliamentary elections that took place on Sunday, and at one of the confrontations, incumbent Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said that if the Socialist Party won again, he would change the law that would make the organization of unreported referendums a crime. Extra oil on fire was added by the leader of the far-right party Vox Santiago Abascal, who at one of the confrontations called on the authorities to arrest Catalan President Quim Torre and bring him to justice for his actions.Visit of King Felipe, who was joined by his wife and daughter, had nothing to do with protests, elections, or independence. The smell of passion did not come to Catalonia, but the family attended the awards ceremony for young entrepreneurs, scientists and artists. Also speaking at the ceremony were his older daughter, 14-year-old Princess Leonor, who will one day succeed her father.
The police barricades prevented anyone from approaching the building where the event took place, and closed city streets for traffic.
In a speech she gave in both Spanish and Catalan, the teenager touched on her love for this part of the homeland, saying that Catalonia has always had a special place in her heart. A challenging feat, meanwhile, was the safety of the kings. Police officers, who were frowning around the Barcelona hall, for example, made it impossible for barricades to get close to the building where the event was taking place, and closed all the main thoroughfares for all traffic.
